item.title: a friendly t-test example
item.description: This dataset is from the car package and includes recall scores as a function of encoding conditions. friendly <- read.csv("friendly.csv") class(friendly) ## [1] "data.frame" Explore the friendly data Get some summary stats from skim() including mini-histograms skim(friendly) ## Skim summary statistics ## n obs: 30 ## n variables: 2 ## ## ── Variable type:factor ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── ## variable missing complete n n_unique top_counts ## condition 0 30 30 3 Bef: 10, Mes: 10, SFR: 10, NA: 0 ## ordered ## FALSE ## ## ── Variable type:integer ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── ## variable missing complete n mean sd p0 p25 p50 p75 p100 hist ## correct 0 30 30 34.

item.title: using R for analysis
item.description: I am feeling more confident about my resolution to get rid of Excel and only use R for data wrangling and visualisation. Next steps… analysis. I’m starting simple (I presume) with t-tests. Mostly commonly I want to determine whether there is a difference in the performance of independent groups of kids, or a difference between kids’ performance on two different conditions, or whether kids are just guessing (i.e. whether their performance differs significantly chance).
